_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
ConAgra International Fertilizer
Victoria, TX.

I.    The Facility Policy:

The management and employees of ConAgra International Fertilizer are committed to the 
prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local responders are 
encouraged to visit the Facility to gain first hand knowledge of the site. 
Employees are required to hold monthly safety meeting and from time to time include 
portions of the management plan in those meetings.  The Facility maintains a internal 
written emergency contingency plan. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is 
prepared to work with local emergency responders, and other authorities to mitigate any 
release, and to minimize the impact of a release on the population and environment.

II.   Facility Information:

The primary activity of the Facility is to distribute agricultural fertilizer for the farming 
community in the area. Anhydrous ammonia is received, store, and used in the production 
of non-hazardous liquid fertilizer solutions. Ammonia is an important source of Nitrogen 
for agricultural crops during the spring and fall of the year.
 
The maximum quantity that can be stored at the facilities stationary storage is 520,000 
pounds.  The typical method of receiving ammonia is by truck transport containing 
40,000 pounds. From time to time the Facility receives ammonia rail cars to use in the 
10-34-0 batch process.  Both the rail cars and transports are unloaded through a transfer 
system designed and maintained in accordance to industry and ANSI Standards for 
handling ammonia.  The 10-34-0 batch process is a large consumer of the product but is 
intermittently operated.  

III.  Accidental Release Prevention:
   
The Facility takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards           
Institute "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" 
K61.1, and Compressed Gas Association CGA G-2 for design, constr

uction, and 
maintenance of the process equipment.  The Facility also incorporates a Process Safety  
Program and mirrors the RMP. The Facility tries to minimize the amount of ammonia 
held or stored at the facility through management judgment. All employees involved with 
the handling of ammonia are trained in their duties. The Facility continues to review and 
look for means to improve operating and best management practices for increase safety. 

IV. The Five Year Accident History:
       
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia related to the operation of this facility 
in  the past five years.  There have been no deaths, injuries, or significant property 
damage at the Facility.  
         
To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, 
property damage, or environmental damage has occurred due to the operation of this 
facility.







Bibliography / References:
Technical Inc. prepared for NIOSH, HAZOP of  "Anhydrous Ammonia Use in 
Agricultural" 1991.

Clements Associates, Inc., Fairfax, VA;  "Health Effects for Ammonia, prepared for The 
Fertilizer Institute.

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  "Chemical Emergency Preparedness and 
Prevention Advisory ? Ammonia", September 1991 Oswer 91-008.2, Series 8; No.2.

Ecology and Environment, Inc.,  "Generic Hazard Assessment and Off-site 
Consequences Analysis Kern and Kings Counties"' prepared for California Fertilizer 
Assoc. October 1990

American National Standard Institute, Inc., "American National Standard Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"  (K-61.1) March 
1989
